body: Try `m = Model(self_=“some URL”)` with the rest of the code as is (from the with-alias example).

@samuelcolvin would having a load alias give you a different function to call that didn’t already have `self` as a parameter? I don’t see that discussed in the linked issue.

Given how frequently the specific field name `self` seems to be desired (I think it has meaning in certain json schema specs), might it make sense to rename `self` to `__self__` or something else equally unlikely to cause conflicts in `BaseModel.__init__` (and perhaps other methods expecting field names as kwargs)? Unless the approach of calling `Model(**data)` to initialize a model becomes discouraged, it feels unfortunate to me to have to change the model initialization code just to support a reasonably-named field (reasonable in a JSON context, rather than a python context anyway).

issue.title: support self argument

repository.name: pydantic
repository.description: Data validation using Python type hints

issue.body:
fix #629

## Checklist

* [x] Unit tests for the changes exist
* [x] Tests pass on CI and coverage remains at 100%
* [ ] ~~Documentation reflects the changes where applicable~~
* [x] `HISTORY.rst` has been updated

body:
Sorry, I'm back at my computer and looking at this properly now.

This should be possible using `parse_obj` (I guess the equivalent of marshmallow's `load`), however at the moment `parse_obj` calls `__init__` in turn thereby raising the same exception.

Would #632 fix this for you? (see the test for usage example)

@samuelcolvin so that would work if 'self' is at the root of the dict but if it's nested it doesn't.
e.g.

```py
from pydantic import BaseModel

class Nested(BaseModel):
    self: str

class Model(BaseModel):
    nested: Nested

m = Model.parse_obj({"nested": {"self": "me"}})
#pydantic.error_wrappers.ValidationError: 1 validation error
#nested
# __init__() got multiple values for argument 'self' (type=type_error)
```
good catch, what about ~~this~~ now I've updated #632?

That seems to do it. Nice.
Just to recap some of the concepts you've discussed here though:

- we would need to user `parse_obj` in order to pass through field names that might clash.
- this prohibits trying to do this with Model(...) straight.

At the risk of going off original topic, you mention using `parse_obj` as a "loader". Would this imply that we could/should overload it to support custom deserialisation?

issue.title: Re-enable nested model init calls while still allowing self

repository.name: pydantic
repository.description: Data validation using Python type hints

issue.body:
## Change Summary

This commit enables nested model `__init__` statements to be executed
while still allowing `self` as an argument.

Effectively reverses the changes from #632 while still enabling the
feature it implemented. In theory, there will still be a collision if
someone ever tried to use `pydantic_base_model/settings_init` as an arg,
but I don't know how to engineer a case where a collision would *never*
happen, I'm not sure there is one.

This commit also added a test for both `BaseModel` and `BaseSettings` for
both the `self`-as-a-parameter and the nested `__init__` features since
`BaseSettings` now has the same issue as `BaseModel` since it invoked
an `__init__` with self.

I have added a comment under the `__init__` for both `BaseModel` and
`BaseSetting` since not having `self` as the first arg is such a
rarity within Python that it will likely confuse future developers who
encounter it.

The actual name of the variable referencing the class itself can be
up for debate.

cc and credit @dgasmith for solution idea

## Related issue number

#632 and #629

<!-- Are there any issues opened that will be resolved by merging this change? -->

## Checklist

* [x] Unit tests for the changes exist
* [x] Tests pass on CI and coverage remains at 100%
* [x] Documentation reflects the changes where applicable
* [x] `HISTORY.rst` has been updated
  * if this is the first change since a release, please add a new section
  * include the issue number or this pull request number `#<number>`
  * include your github username `@<whomever>`

body:
I'd like to possibly re-open this issue and further discuss the validity of this feature within Pydantic. Particularly the fact that `self` has a very well established and understood meaning in the Python world (https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008/#id46) and loss of the ability to do `Model(**kwargs)` is a very non-Pythonic way of doing things. Also feel free to just shoot this discussion down since Python conventions are only that and not really enforceable.

I worry that defining an attribute within Python classes called `self` will very quickly lead to confusion among Python-centric users. I'm not versed in JSON API at all, but the use case for `self` seems a bit narrow from what I can read (I can't find a use case for `kwargs`, but I would be very interested to see one!). I don't want to discount it entirely, but I wanted to talk about it. I have an implementation in #644 to fix an inheritance bug, but it required me to choose a different arg than `self`. 

Given that Pydantic is not JSON (although it does support interfaces to JSON Schema Core, JSON Schema Validation, and OpenAPI, but not JSON API), I'm not sure of the merits of putting this in because `self` is a neigh hallowed word in the Python world; and it makes me uneasy even in my own implementation. Even an attribute like `self.self` is very rare. I'm happy to discuss options, but I'm not sure I fully agree with this as a base-line feature from a (personal) Python-centric view.

A possible alternate solution would be to make a special Type in Pydantic which can handle this so allowing `self` becomes a special case rather than the base line as I have implemented in #644, although I worry doing so would just make a special `BaseModel` which can have `self` in it serving to create just a derivative of `BaseModel` rather than a simple Type like `datetime`.

Another option would be to have the pre-formatter as suggested above, which maps an arg like `self` to something else until the init is done and then you can have `self.self` internally if you need to, but I don't know how efficient that would be since it effectively adds a special case to all `__init__` calls. But these are implementation details rather than the philosophical details I'm more concerned about.

I suppose the broader issue here is that the first arg of Python class in its code automatically becomes an unusable keyword arg, and there is no way around that. For example, in #644 I use `pydantic_base_model_init` instead of `self`, which will have the same problem as using `self` did pre-#632 if someone ever tried to use "pydantic_base_model_init" as one of their attributes. So my take is that if we have to have one word blocked out, it may as well be `self` since most Python users will likely be aware of it, or at minimum understand why that particular word is blocked if they try to use it.

Thinking about this a bit more, I'm being a bit over-zealous about this. My implementation in #644 has the non-self term only showing up in the `init` call, everywhere else the `self` is used, it's a very minor change in the grand scheme of things, and it works. 

There are still the outstanding things of something possibly colliding with `pydantic_base_model_init `, but if that's a concern we can pick some random valid python-variable-name string. Then there is the double edge case where someone inherits and modifies `__init__` + tries to use `self` as the first arg + is trying to use "self" as an attribute (either as the model or inherited) which can all be fixed by "don't use self in the `__init__` as you are already are using it as an attribute"

Shorter: I think I'm actually fine with this, a little uneasy, but its small corner cases and arguing for convention rather than functionality.
